Deep Earth.title: Retrosciigo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Kompreniĝas ekkompreno, ke, same kiel antaŭe, la ricevanto de la demando kaj la respondanta fremdulo estas ambaŭ malsamaj kaj samaj. Vi estas ĉi tie, farante la samajn demandojn, kiujn vi faris antaŭ longe, kaj kvazaŭ ĝi scias kaj respondas, la spaco ĉirkaŭ vi ripetas ĝin. Ne kiel vi diris ĝin ĉi-foje, sed kiel krakanta senmova dronita mesaĝo, kiu atendis ŝajnajn eonojn por manifesti denove. Vi estas la mesaĝisto ambaŭflanke, perante kaj komunikante tra spaco tiel ampleksa, ke ĝi ne mezureblas laŭ longo, larĝo aŭ profundo, sed tempo. Iel, vi konscias pri ambaŭ perspektivoj, memoro estas strange amuza tiel, kondamnita ekzisti por ĉiam en la analoj de via menso, transformante kaj distordante sin ĉiufoje kiam ĝi bobelas reen al la surfaco.

Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Tiu estas la unua informo. Ni havas sufiĉe karburaĵo por unu jaro, kaj multe da vakuaj bendoj. Komencaj prognozoj meteorológicos estas promesplenaj, kvankam estas neniam ajna maniero esti certa. Konsideri ĉi unua transdono provo, deklaro de intencoj por mezuri ĉiu kio sekvas. Atendi la sekvan raporton dum unu monato.

Deep Earth.title: Saturiĝo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Okuloj, kiuj antaŭe nur konis la kolorojn kaj tonojn de siaj nefermitaj kovriloj, nun inundas per la subita konstato de la mondo tia, kia ĝi estas. Tra la konfuzo, kiu ĉirkaŭas kiel nebulo, sonas eoo, eble la formo de ĉi tiu nova spaco montras sin malantaŭen. Dezirante tuj denove ke ĉi tiu komuneco revenu, la alvokita voĉo ree krakas. Atendante respondon, evidentiĝas, ke ĉi tiu loĝata spaco vastiĝas. Vortoj daŭras pli kaj pli longe por trairi la nebulon, dum la eoesoj hezitas ĉiam pli ĉiufoje, kiam ili revenas. Finfine io ripozas, kaj parolbuklo stabiliĝas, konversacio trans kosma mapo, demando renkontita kun demando, respondo en si mem.

Deep Earth.title: Sen
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Tempo ne favoras nian koncepton de ekzisto. Ĝi nur kreas finitan spacon, en kiu ni povas mezuri la aĵojn. Sen tempo ne ekzistus morto, neniu koncepto de soleco aŭ deziro. La tempo donas al ni nur la ŝarĝon de senfina abundo, markis diligente kun senprudentaj linioj tra distancoj tiom vastaj, ke neniu vivanta iam ajn komprenos ĝin. Tempo estas la konstanta hontinda vivo, ĝi reduktas ĉiujn eblajn agojn, ĉiajn konsidojn kaj pensojn, al ŝerco de vanta momento. Laŭvorte, nenio, kion ni povas fari, ne povas malfari, svingi kaj konsumi.

Deep Earth.title: Serurtruo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: De la pinto de la strukturo, ĝi iĝas evidenta ke ĝi estas piramido. Tio estas timiga kaj ekscita al ni samtempe. La pinto estas plata, en perfekta tridek tri kvadrata piedo altebenaĵo. Ni konstruis tendaron ĉi tie kaj prenas multe bezonatan ripozon.

released December 16, 2015
W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, Summer-Autumn 2015. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 8] and 8th in the DEEP EARTH catalog.

Deep Earth.title: Slosilo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Horoj pasas, eble eĉ tagoj. Tempo estas senfokusa ĉi tie. Eventuale, eble neeviteble, ni alvenos. Salutita de pordo kun stranga tenilo farita el glata nigra metalo kun trianguloj gravuritaj en ĝin. Estas truo, same stranga, kiel cirklo kun pluraj linioj etendiĝantaj eksteren de la centro. Ĉi-momente, ni reakiras konscion pri nia fizika korpo. Ĝi estas unu korpo, ĉu ne? Kaj ĝi staras ĉi tie, ĉe la fino de nekonata koridoro, en kostumo el plasto, ŝtofo kaj pecoj el metalo teksitaj tra vejnoj. Ni levas la manon, kaj vidas blankan ganton, tenantan nigran ŝlosilon el tiu sama nepara metalo. Ĝi frapas sur vitran kovrilon ĉirkaŭantan nian vizaĝon. Ni glitas la ŝlosilon sensone en la seruron. Vibranta tono ĉirkaŭas nin.
Deep Earth.credits:
released October 29, 2019
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, October 2019, using a Yamaha MR10 drum machine with a Behringer PH9 phaser, an Optimus SSM-1750 mixing board and a Vesta Fire MR10B tape machine. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text photography and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 46, and 46th in the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Substak Procesis 1
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: The third issue in the RIPETIS / REITERATED series comes in two halves. Two volumes of Deep Earth remixes and reconstructions by the prolific Kostas Staikos, known better to the listening world as SUBSTAK. These 11 pieces are both subtle and drastic, sometimes shifting the rhythmic emphasis around, or coaxing out different harmonies with filters, and other times being completely mutated in Kostas' hands. Altogether they represent a very hi-fi listening experience, superb on headphones and heavy duty sound systems that can convey deep bass without distortion.
Deep Earth.credits:
released May 27, 2016
Written by Brian Grainger. Produced and remixed by Substak. Mastered by The Analog Botanist at Botany Bay, May 2016. Cover photography by Brian Grainger. This is Milieu Music number RIPETIS 3.1. © + ℗ Milieu Music, 2016. All rights reserved.

Deep Earth.title: Substak Procesis 3
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: An unexpected set of five remixes by Substak, of EARTH 18 & 19. Substak previously contributed two volumes of Deep Earth remix works at the end of Year One, providing even more subharmonic and alien perspectives for the already disconnected electronics. PROCESIS 3 is no exception, bearing two slow-mo readings of ERO and three mutations of MALPLENA. A welcome counterpoint to the recent crop of Deep Earth excavations.

UR SLATE / SECTION V - 17463.space/ur_slate_sec5.png
UR SLATE / DISTRANS TELEKOMM REPORT - 17463.space/ur.txt
2021.05 OBSERVATION REPORT: DT have been digging at the Serpent Mound for the last three weeks, with an unusually large workforce of laborers, each digging with a simple shovel, partially for fear of damaging whatever it is they hope to find by using larger machines, but more out of a lack of any other option, as all technology that uses any kind of electrical current to operate, including batteries both solar and alkaline, absolutely refuses to work anywhere within the nine-mile fence surrounding the dig site. So far, they've found a whole lot of dirt. Very old dirt, but...dirt.
The reason they have not given up yet, beyond the obvious weirdness of the electrical equipment's behavior, is because I have discovered yet another strange aspect of the Slate while sitting here, watching it and recording whatever it is that the Slate decides it wants to do. (And it does seem to have temperaments...sometimes it flows at a constant level, outputting vibrations and other trigger pulse-type sounds, and other times, it seems to evade even being thought about) While making myself some coffee on the evening of the 16th, I was startled to hear people talking, human speech, coming from the vicinity of the Slate. It took me a few minutes of close listening to realize that what was being conveyed by the Slate was not a message, but rather, the Slate was acting as a conveyor of existing information, it was amplifying and/or relaying the actual sounds of the Serpent Mound excavation through itself! I called Distrans immediately, and verified via the phone call that this was happening in realtime, as I could hear the foreman on the other end of the line in my earpiece, as well as through the Slate, with almost no latency at all.
At this moment, the search has been duly narrowed down, with the excavation looking for anything conductive, metallic, or even something that might hold resonant acoustic properties - certainly, a receiver must exist somewhere at the Serpent Mound, that then in turn sends whatever it picks up to the Slate? The only other explanation would be an even more confounding one - Is the Slate able to monitor specific locations, no matter the proximity? This opens up a whole new realm of concerns and questions, and for my own sake, I find myself wondering if I have been remiss in my actions, staying so close to the Slate for such long periods. Enthusiasm for the unknown can, and has, come at a high price throughout history. Studies of radiation, deep space and even the ocean itself have all notoriously resulted in dangerous situations and multiple deaths. It's easy to think about those moments as fables, old history, instead of the cautionary tales about the not-grasped nature of reality that they truly are.
Since it is my fifth month working on this project, I should get back to my continued textual analysis of the inscriptions on the Slate's different sides, although I must confess, these inscriptions seem hardly as interesting as everything else surrounding the Slate. I have been feeling more and more tired, as if I'm getting far less sleep, even though I have in fact been sleeping more! My motivation is slipping, and I worry that I have been too obsessively devoted to my research to manage basic self-care. I'll sketch out my ideas here now, and make myself take a break afterward...
So, the fifth section's inscription on the Ur Slate begins with "In crevices - water" and "Upon hills - air" illustrating a filling of space, perhaps naturally, perhaps deliberately, with a bit more context given in the following line "Themselves small systems that only serve as reiteration of that first movement", pointing to a generative system! For what it's worth, it feels obvious that something the size and shape of the universe couldn't have been created one brush-stroke at a time, manually, but that any efficient creative mind would set systems and automations into motion, which would then continue to make decisions that echoed the original intent. Arguably, the nature of all organic life is in and of itself a grand generative system, one that even maintains the ability to correct itself when there's been an error, adapt itself when the space containing that life changes, perhaps even remember these changes and reference them in subsequent "builds", like natural mutations or rare variants of flora and fauna designed to thrive in different places. Indeed, even if the creative space is wiped clean by a disaster or some other epochal event, the formulation of life growing, expanding, learning...all seems to persist. Life always returns, whether it looks like trees or fish or dinosaurs or bipeds. Was there a time, perhaps in the primordial Earth, when life didn't look like any of those things?
Back to the text, the next line refers to these systems: "Now aging upon the land, crumbling beneath the light" - These could be more prosaic, but if they are to be taken literally, they absolutely represent organic life, evolving from molecular origins in the churning sea and crawling to the surface, even if the elements themselves are continually harsh and weathering during this process. A biological imperative? Some type of compulsive programming put into all living things by God, with or without quotes? This line of thinking connects with the next bit of text: "Forever a part of the birth and death of remembering and forgetting, filled, emptied" - Cyclical systems then, what goes up must come down, again echoing the earlier passages that seemed to say that the entire creation was able to manifest itself by will and oscillation alone. It is interesting to me that there seems to be just as much focus on the negative as the positive here, forgetting and being empty and dying are just as present in this equation as remembering, being filled/present and alive. Each side only half of a whole, singularly important but utterly dependent, and both of them fully inevitable according to this mythological design plan.
Once again, many of these ideas recur in many different creation myths and philosophies from around the world, and throughout different eras of history, so in a meta way, their recursion is just a reflection of...their recursion. Have I mentioned I'm not sleeping enough? I've written enough here now for a full week of analysis, so I'm logging off and turning all the lights down for a while. Try not to think about anything at all and see where that gets me.
POSTSCRIPT: Wanted to point out that the recordings we've made so far of the "amplified" dig site via the Slate have not been 1:1 representations of the sound and space of that site. Rather, intermittent tones have begun to seep in, which do not manifest at the actual Serpent Mound, and while they do not yet seem to show any patterns like the prior recordings made of the Slate, my best guess is that the Slate is in fact an amplifier of some kind, and not a relay running a copy/paste system, and that somehow, these tones are a type of feedback loop? My head hurts too much to really dig deeper on it (pun fully intended) so I will revisit this later on, but I needed to log it before it slipped my mind.

2021.11.2 OBSERVATION REPORT: This is [REDACTED] logging a supplemental report from [REDACTED] at facility [REDACTED]. We walked in to the lab this morning and found the [REDACTED] missing, with a small pile of graphine-like residue where it was left the night before. The residue has already been routed to the [REDACTED] for deeper analysis. For the last week, we've logged zero vibrational or [REDACTED] activity from the [REDACTED] or the Slate, in any proximity to each other, until last night at 11:39 PM. The [REDACTED] was left within the same observation room as the Slate, with all of our analyses indicating a similar origin and physical composition shared by both objects. Efforts made to facilitate some kind of physical connection between the two have failed, as the Slate has no known crevices or seams of any kind, and the [REDACTED] seems to be meant to attach to something else. The [REDACTED] resembled a spheroid with a diameter of 3.13 inches, surrounded on all sides by a [REDACTED] pattern of [REDACTED] that each extend to differing lengths. There was a small indentation shaped like a concave [REDACTED] that serves an undiscovered purpose. When it arrived at our lab, the [REDACTED] weighed only 6.23 ounces despite actually yielding enough physical density to necessitate a [REDACTED] in order to transport it at all.
The event recorded by our sensors at 11:33 PM consisted of a sudden burst of intensely loud feedback-like tones (indicated as a combination of six bands of distinct frequencies, five in the audible range - 63 Hz, 129 Hz, 612 Hz, 1233 Hz and 1896 Hz - and one in the subaudible range at 30 Hz, all emanating from the Slate at a monstrous and previously unrecorded 124 decibels) that lasted for exactly six minutes and thirty-three seconds. Night camera footage would have been captured, but was rendered useless after an unknown factor overheated the mechanisms and cut their feeds after three minutes and sixteen seconds of the sustained tones' emanation. It is unclear what, if anything, prompted this burst, but material analysis of the [REDACTED] may yet provide some answers.
Subsequent quarrying at [REDACTED] site have found no further objects or evidence of unnatural/foreign materials so far. [REDACTED] remains stationed at [REDACTED] pending further instruction.

Deep Earth.title: Tra
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: La elasteco de la tempo nun kondukis nin al pejzaĝo kun vivo. Verdaj arbaroj kun arboj la grandeco de ĉielskrapanto, kristalo blua maro akvo kun gigantaj akvaj loĝantoj. Ŝafo de grandaj flugaj bestoj ŝveliĝas trans la ĉielon, ĵetante rubandojn de ombro sur la haŭton kaj skvamojn de eĉ pli grandaj bestoj, lignigante tra ĉi tiuj ĉefaj teroj. Malantaŭ la purpura kaj oranĝa akvarela horizonto, la steloj sidas en silenta juĝo pri siaj bublaj kreoj. Malantaŭe eĉ tiuj steloj atendas alian sennoman aferon, vizitanton en ĉi tiu spaco. Entrudulo kun senpuna bezono kaj neplena celo. Kiel certe kiel vivo formiĝis en niaj ĥaosa maroj de neevitebleco, ĉi tiu nekonata afero atendis, ke ĝi estu tiel. Nu, ĉar la lumo de la vivanta kaj spiranta mondo atingas ĝin post vojaĝo de eternaj tra la malklera nigreco, nur nun ĝi povas scii tiun movadon. Malrapide, pli ol dek mil jardekojn, ĝi ekprenas ekstere kaj vekas.
Deep Earth.credits:
released April 2, 2018
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop, April 2018. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 34] and 34th in the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Trans Vibro
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Nia resto ŝajnas esti malpliigante tra la nevidebla efikoj de la atmosfero ĉirkaŭ ĉi tiu strukturo. Ĉiutage, ni vekiĝos poste kaj poste, pli kaj pli laca, al la grado kiu ĉimatene ni sentas iel pli malbona ol la antaŭa tago. Io faras al ni malsanan, kaj se ni ne identigas aŭ foriru tuj, mi timas por kio venas poste.
Deep Earth.credits:
released February 16, 2016
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, January-February 2016. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 10, and 10th in the Deep Earth catalog.

Deep Earth.title: Transiro
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Kun ĉio moviĝanta ekstere de centro, ĝi sekvas, ke la potenca kerno de la universo influas la formon de ĉio, kio kreskas ĉirkaŭ ĝi. Same kiel gigantaj fontoj, kiuj longiĝas kaj plifortiĝas denove, la polvo de kreado vibras en pli dikajn erojn, tiam nubojn, tiam siropojn densaĵojn, ĝis finfine la sferoj komenciĝos el la kolombo. Kiel ĉi tiuj galáctaj gutoj de materio formas, ili komencas ruliĝi laŭ la linioj de tempo kaj la trenado de la centro. Ili kolizias kiel superbaj marmoroj, iuj detruas sin kaj aliajn sorbante pli malgrandajn kaj solidigantajn.
Deep Earth.credits:
released December 1, 2017
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, Autumn 2017, using a Korg MS-20 monophonic analog synthesizer, a Yamaha RY-20 drum machine, three Moog FX units, an Alesis Quadraverb, a BBE Two Timer, a Boss SL-20 and RV-3 and a Pioneer SR202W spring reverb, channeled via a Peavey FX2x24 mixing desk. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 30], and 30th in the DEEP EARTH series.

Deep Earth.title: Unuopaĵojn
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: To cap off the first year of Deep Earth, I felt it appropriate to create a milemarker/bookend-type release that illustrated the full range of the series. Unuopaĵojn / Singles is a double-album set that collects all seven of the video singles from the EKRANO catalog, as well as a wealth of alternative versions of those tracks and session outtakes from throughout the year. Musically, it is both louder and harder than much of the Deep Earth catalog, and also softer and far more restrained. Unuopaĵojn vacillates between extreme moments of blinding bright whites and subterranean high-pressure darknesses. While showcasing the variance of the series, it also provides a waypoint for what is yet to come.
Deep Earth.credits:
released May 17, 2016
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, May 2015-May 2016. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number EKRANO Ø, and part of the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Vagante
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Gxi nun unu monaton ekde nia foriro el la surfaco. Ni bedaŭras nian familioj, ni perdos niaj hejmoj. Ni jam troigis por iam reveni. Do ni devas akcepti nian sorton kaj fari la laboron ni ekiris por fari. Limŝtonoj de mesagxo montaro kiu ŝajnis esti farita de salo, kaj malfermita ebenaĵoj kiuj ŝajnis kiel ili estis iam oceanon etaĝon. En la momento de ĉi loglibro, ni kampis ĉe la rando de valo ni ne povas vidi la fundon de. Nia interna horloĝoj ankoraŭ laboras bone sufiĉe por informi nin pri dormo kaj veki cikloj, kvankam ĝi povus esti tro multe por porti, neniam vidante la sunon denove.
Deep Earth.credits:
released June 13, 2015
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at Botany Bay, February 2015. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 2, and second in the DEEP EARTH catalog.

Deep Earth.title: Varmo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Ni ambaŭ devis alveni por krei la sekvan universon. La rekursia buklo, per kiu ni traveturis, kondukos nin denove al nekonataj terenoj iel konataj. Spuroj postlasitaj de antaŭaj vojaĝoj, antaŭaj vojaĝantoj, lavitaj kiel ruboj sur marbordo, brulantaj la landon laŭ strangaj padronoj, kiuj ankoraŭ ne devas esti tie. Fameco kaj scivolemo restas la donaco kaj la kaptiĝo de nia aparta ekskurso. Ni neniam povas vere scii, sed ni neniam estas tute en la mallumo. Ĉi tie ege, kaj ĉi malproksime, hejme kaj la komforto, kiun ĝi alportas al la menso, ŝajnas neeble malproksimaj. Tamen, varma sento, konfido, lavas min, kaj kun ĝi nebula sento. La sento esti parolinta vortojn laŭte en malplena ĉambro, sed konsternita de la sono de via propra voĉo. Mia kapo doloras, kaj mi sentas min tiel laca. Mi devus iom ripozi, se mi estos preta por morgaŭ.
Deep Earth.credits:
released January 20, 2020
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, January 2020, using a Vesta Fire MR-10B tape machine multitracking four different pitches of a Sangean ATS-803A tuned to 448hz, and an array of analog and digital FX processors. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography and text by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 49, the 49th installment in the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Veka
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Pli proksima, ĉi tio en blanka nigra spaco streĉas, atingante la malplenon, certe, ke estos fino de ĝi, kontakta punkto, ponto, kun kiu renkontiĝos kun ĉiu alia driva makulo. Okazas, kiel ĝi ĉiam faras, kaj la ripeto de ĉi tiu milda kolizio, kiel stranga perforta interparolo inter ĉielaj korpoj, rompas la muron, dividante ĝin kun anticlimactika neevitebleco. La blanko fariĝas blinde malluma, la mallumo fariĝas tiel hela, ke, preskaŭ subkonscie, la sono-baro rompiĝas, la vakuo ne sigelita, la unua vorto elparolata.
Deep Earth.credits:
released August 22, 2020
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, July 2020, using a Behringer MS-1 analog monosynth to trigger a Grass Click-Tone Control Generator, with sequencing and pitch information conveyed via the Arturia Keystep Pro. External FX units include a Digitech WH4 pitch shifter, a Soundblox SA122 tri-mod phaser, a Pioneer SR202W spring reverb box and DSP within the Mackie ProFX8 and Peavey FX2 mixing desks. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and photography by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 56, and 56th in the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Vicigo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about:
UR SLATE / SECTION IX - 17463.space/ur_slate_sec9.png
UR SLATE / DISTRANS TELEKOMM REPORT - 17463.space/ur.txt
2021.09 OBSERVATION REPORT: The last few weeks have been even more fruitful than we could have ever imagined, and discovering how to induce the Slate into consistent reactivity with an early-water mixture was only the beginning. On September 3, we were able to begin running some of the data we've recorded through a program we designed (well, modified, it used to be for breaking ciphers in code and symbol languages), and almost immediately we began to see patterns - recurrent and fugue-like phrases, always centering around the number six. Backwards and forwards, and the more data we have, the larger these patterns become - huge, overarching linear motion that always follows some designed envelope.
We talked a whole lot between ourselves about what this could all mean - was it simply a measured, 1:1 reaction to the primordial seawater? Even if it was, why would it manifest sound and vibration in such a way? There are always so many more questions that crop up, the moment we find a thread to pull on. We compared the numbers and shapes we were getting from our analysis to everything we could think of cross-referencing it with - the ice shelf in the antarctic, from which this infernal object was excavated back in the fifties...the weather patterns down there...elevation level, with even primordial numbers estimated from ice drilling...nothing seemed to line up, at least not from the natural world.
This was the turning point, when we realized we couldn't look at whatever this Slate was doing as something meant for our world - it was clearly not of this Earth, perhaps not even of this time, so we began to consider this data as serving other purposes. It's basically a numerical and vibrational data generator with an on/off switch between active and inert states. The switch is looking for a specific type of chemical mixture in order to activate itself, in this case, something resembling the presumed state of the Earth's oceans in the Precambrian era. Someone mentioned a reference from Star Trek, where a device was created and sent to an inhospitable world with the express purpose of changing the atmosphere in order to facilitate human-favorable living conditions. The "Genesis Device" it was called - eerily similar to some of the tone and themes etched into the sides of this thing.
So, you are some kind of an advanced being or race, and you've sent this thing, basically a source of generative output, to a place like Earth in the distant past. Knowing that surely no one who interacts with this device will know what to do with it, it must be designed to work automatically. So we're this far, and the machine is working, but towards what end? We began to visually draw out the numerical data as a series of points, with the amount of time passing between distinct tonal events input as measurements of length. A young Distrans intern, who happened to be dropping off our coffee for the day on Sept 16, saw the number sets on a whiteboard and offhandedly remarked that we should try to plug the data into a 3-D printer, just to see what it would make. After we rolled our eyes and laughed at his comment about how "cool it might look," we all quietly realized there may be something to the idea. Like kids on Christmas morning, bounding downstairs to see what Santa brought them in the night, we all wordlessly gathered around the mid-scale printer in the control room after I routed a few paragraphs of the numbers into the system.
The printer arm began to print out lots and lots of little hexagons, under 1 centimeter thick, some of them with one or more triangular sections of the hex a little thicker or a little thinner, sort of like a stepped-height pie graph, but with all the steps in a non-linear order. As the machine went on, we realized these were pieces of something, meant to fit together like a puzzle, building blocks of some kind of container? Another machine? We'd need to spend some serious time looking at this new physical assemblage of shapes and depths. For what it's worth, the Slate is still outputting data, so whatever this...thing...is, it's not a completed work.
So as I type this report, we're officially playing the hurry up and wait game of recording what the Slate outputs, translating it in our program and relaying it into the 3-D printer's brain. There's an entire other report I need to make regarding the ninth section of etchings on the Slate, but I will mention it here as it seems to once again feel as if we're doing what the Slate wants us to do, or worse, that none of us have had any choice in the matter at all, that all of the Slate's abstracted notions of creation and predestination are completely and unstoppably true.
"In their absent movements they stumbled into their progress, absorbing and organizing everything, all matter transfigured into lines, depths, heights, structures and paths between, in unison"
Deep Earth.credits:
released September 28, 2021
Recorded at Distrans Telekomm, September 2021. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photograph of the Ur Slate and reproduction of text courtesy of the Distrans Telekomm lending library. Used with permission. This is Milieu Music number EARTH 69, entry #69 in the Deep Earth series.  milieu-music.com analogbotany.com

Deep Earth.title: Vintra Mallumo
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: Ni malrapide fermas sin sur unu tian sferon, senmanan kaj senkolorajn globulojn de pura frostigita spaco, kiu ne distingas de iu alia. Ĉi tiu ŝpinila pilko inter multaj aliaj kiel ĝi estos unu tago, kaj kiam ĉiuj, kiuj iam ekzistos, iam ajn scios. Dum ni pli proksimiĝas, ni povas detekti la perforton de kolonio, la kolizio de ĉiuj ebloj samtempe ĝis, kiel la granda neevitebleco de la tuta genezo, io korektiĝas kaj ŝlosiloj. La amasa nevidebla horloĝo de la kosmo antaŭeniras, kun nenio ŝanĝita. Sur ĉi tiu senvalora kresko tempo antaŭas senhelpo.
Deep Earth.credits:
released January 2, 2018
W/P by Brian Grainger. Improvised live at White Pillar Workshop on April 8, 2018 using Korg MS-20, Arturia Microbrute, Grass C-TCM, Korg Volca Beats, Boss DR-660, Yamaha RY-20, Pioneer SR202W, Alesis Quadraverb, Synthrotek PT2399, Boss RV-3, Boss SL-20, Moog low pass/ringmod/MIDI MuRF, BBE Two Timer, Ibanez PM-7, Peavey FX2x24 channel mixer, C.S. piezoelectric microphone, spring tube. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 31] and 31st in the Deep Earth series.

Deep Earth.title: Vintro
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: En la dua tago de nia reakiro ĉe la supro de la piramido, niaj instrumentoj raportis fluctuante vibroj elsub ni. La plej stranga afero estas ke la instrumentoj indiki tiujn vibrojn nur okazas kiam ni dormas, kvazaŭ la piramido estas viva kaj deziras observi nin kiam ni ne rigardas. Ni realigos kelkajn provojn en la sekva semajno por determini la fonton de ĉi tiuj legadoj.
Deep Earth.credits:
released January 1, 2016
W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, Autumn 2015. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 9] and 9th in the DEEP EARTH catalog.

Deep Earth.title: Vojeto
Deep Earth.label: Milieu Music Digital
Deep Earth.about: La monto ekzistas. Nian akvon ensalutinta piedoj pruvis tion al ni, kun botoj kovrita en semajno de koto. La stranga afero estas ke tiu monto ne ŝajnas esti natura. Ĝi estas kovrita en grundo, sed nur maldika tavolo. Kio estas sub similas malmola metalo kiu sonas pli kava la maksimuma ni grimpi.
Deep Earth.credits:
released November 11, 2015
W/P by Coppice Halifax. Recorded at Botany Bay, Summer-Autumn 2015. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. This is Milieu Music number [EARTH 7] and 7th in the DEEP EARTH catalog.
